newsitem.title: CANADA: Corel CEO sees Q4 sales of US$130 mln.
newsitem.headline: Corel CEO sees Q4 sales of US$130 mln.

text.p: Corel Corp president and chief executive officer Michael Cowpland said on Thursday he expected the company's sales to rise to about US$130 million in the fourth quarter from the US$84.94 million in the third quarter this year.
He also said he expected Corel to return to profitability in the fourth quarter after delayed product shipments resulted in a loss of US$0.05 a share in the third quarter.
"We expect growth to be outstanding," Cowpland told a breakfast meeting. "Now we are beginning to accelerate into good profits."
Cowpland also said he expected the early November release of the new version of its flagship product, the DRAW 7 software, to be the "best release to date."

He said said he expects an International Trade Tribunal decision on Corel's request for a probe into why Canada's Defence Department chose rival Microsoft Corp's Office software over Corel's WordPerfect.

The Canadian government awarded the C$8.6 million (US$6.28 million) contract to Microsoft in June for 40,000 installations of Microsoft's Office Suite, which includes word processing and other software.
"We know it's being reviewed and that in itself is significant," Cowpland said, "We expect the results from it in the next two months."
